title: Key Contacts
text:
Protocol ID: ONB-CONTACTS-001
Version: v1
Author: Dillon Corvino

title: Key Contacts
text:
Purpose
This page lists key contacts relevant to PhD students and lab members at IMMEI.
It is intended to: - Make it clear who to contact for what - Avoid delays caused by uncertainty or misdirected requests - Centralise institute and lab-level contact information
If unsure who to contact, ask your supervisor or institute management.

title: Key Contacts
text:
Institute administration and coordination

Institute Management
Lucie Hrvat-Delforge
Contact for: - Institute-level administrative questions
- Onboarding coordination at IMMEI
- Contracts, appointments, and general organisational matters
- Institute procedures and internal processes



Science Management / Safety Coordination
Dr. Johanna Breuer
Contact for: - S2 induction organisation - Waste disposal procedures - Safety-related questions and compliance - Guidance on biosafety, chemical safety, and institute regulations
- Coordination of safety trainings and documentation
If a topic relates to safety, waste, or regulatory compliance at IMMEI, Johanna is the correct first contact.

title: Key Contacts
text:
Core facilities and technical infrastructure

Flow Cytometry Core Facility (FCCF)
Andreas Dolf
Contact for: - FCCF induction and training - Access to flow cytometry instruments - Questions about instrument suitability for a project - Scheduling introductions to FCCF workflows
All new users must arrange an introduction before using FCCF instruments.

title: Key Contacts
text:
Animal facility

Animal Facility / iFET Management
Daniela Krauss
Contact for: - Access to the animal facility - Required inductions and approvals - General questions about animal work administration - Coordination of introductions for new users
Mouse colony and experiment management is handled via PyRAT.

title: Key Contacts
text:
General guidance

For scientific questions, start with your supervisor

For administrative or onboarding issues, contact institute management

For safety, waste, or regulatory matters, contact science management

For facility access, contact the relevant facility lead

If you are unsure who to contact, ask early—misdirected requests slow everyone down.

title: Key Contacts
text:
Notes
Contacts and responsibilities may evolve.
If a role changes or a new contact becomes relevant, this page should be updated to remain accurate.

title: Lab Etiquette
text:
Protocol ID: GEN-LAB-ETQ-001
Version: v1
Author: Dillon Corvino

title: Lab Etiquette
text:
Purpose
This document describes day-to-day lab etiquette in the Abdullah Lab.
Its goal is to: - Prevent avoidable friction - Ensure shared spaces remain functional - Make expectations explicit rather than assumed
These guidelines apply to all lab members and complement the broader principles described in Lab Expectations.

title: Lab Etiquette
text:
General principle
The lab is a shared working environment.
A simple rule applies: > Leave spaces, equipment, and reagents in a state that you would be happy to find them.

title: Lab Etiquette
text:
Benches and workspaces

Bench use

Keep benches as clear as possible
Only keep materials required for current work on the bench
Return shared items when finished



End of day expectations
At the end of the day: - Dispose of waste appropriately - Wipe down the bench if work involved spills or biological material - Return equipment and reagents to their designated locations
Benches should not accumulate long-term storage or unused items.

title: Lab Etiquette
text:
Shared equipment

General use

Treat shared equipment with care
Follow posted instructions and lab norms
Do not modify settings without understanding the impact on others



After use

Clean equipment if required
Reset settings if you changed them
Report malfunctions or damage promptly

If equipment is left unusable, the next user is delayed.

title: Lab Etiquette
text:
Fridges, freezers, and storage

Labelling
All stored items must be clearly labelled with: - Name or initials - Contents - Date
Unlabelled or outdated items may be removed during clean-ups.


Organisation

Respect designated areas and shelves
Do not move or discard others’ samples without discussion
Avoid overcrowding shared storage

title: Lab Etiquette
text:
Reagents and consumables

Close containers properly
Do not return contaminated reagents to stock
Inform the lab if common reagents are running low
Do not use unlabelled or expired reagents

If unsure about a reagent’s status, ask before using it.

title: Lab Etiquette
text:
Tissue culture areas

Follow sterile technique consistently
Clean work areas before and after use
Dispose of waste correctly
Do not leave flasks or plates without clear labelling

Tissue culture spaces must be kept especially orderly to protect all users.

title: Lab Etiquette
text:
Booking and fairness
Where equipment or space is shared: - Be considerate of others’ time - Cancel bookings you do not need - Avoid monopolising resources
If you need extended or unusual access, communicate this in advance.

title: Lab Etiquette
section: Noise, interruptions, and shared space awareness
text:
Noise, interruptions, and shared space awareness

Be mindful of noise levels in shared areas
Keep phone calls and meetings from disrupting others
Respect that others may be concentrating or running time-sensitive experiments

title: Lab Etiquette
text:
Food, drink, and personal items

Follow safety rules regarding food and drink in lab areas
Keep personal items out of experimental spaces
Store food only in designated areas

title: Lab Etiquette
text:
Problems, mistakes, and accountability
Mistakes happen.
If something goes wrong: - Inform relevant lab members promptly - Do not hide problems or hope they go unnoticed - Work collaboratively to resolve issues
Early communication prevents small problems from becoming larger ones.

title: Lab Etiquette
text:
Scope
This document focuses on practical etiquette, not: - Scientific judgement - Performance evaluation - Institutional policy
When in doubt, default to clear communication and consideration for others.

title: Lab Etiquette
text:
Notes
These guidelines reflect current lab practice and may evolve.
Suggestions for improvement are welcome and should be raised so expectations remain clear and fair.

title: Lab Expectations
text:
Protocol ID: GEN-LAB-EXP-001
Version: v1
Author: Dillon Corvino

title: Lab Expectations
text:
Purpose
This document outlines the shared expectations for all members of the Abdullah Lab.
Its purpose is to: - Provide clarity on how the lab functions day to day - Set common standards for conduct, communication, and responsibility - Support a professional, respectful, and productive research environment
These expectations apply to all lab members, including PhD students, postdoctoral researchers, technicians, and visiting researchers.

title: Lab Expectations
text:
General principles
The Abdullah Lab values: - Scientific integrity and reproducibility - Mutual respect and professionalism - Open communication - Shared responsibility for the lab environment
Expectations are framed to support independence while ensuring that work remains transparent, collaborative, and reproducible.

title: Lab Expectations
text:
Professional conduct
Lab members are expected to: - Treat colleagues with respect at all times - Communicate constructively, even in disagreement - Be reliable and follow through on agreed tasks - Contribute positively to the lab environment
Discriminatory, dismissive, or unprofessional behaviour is not acceptable.
Concerns should be raised early, either directly or via a supervisor, before issues escalate.

title: Lab Expectations
text:
Scientific integrity and documentation
All work conducted in the lab must meet high standards of scientific integrity.
Expectations include: - Experiments are planned thoughtfully and documented clearly - Data are recorded contemporaneously and accurately - Deviations from protocols are noted - Data and reagents are traceable
Lab members must follow the lab’s Data Management and Reproducibility Standards, including: - Use of experiment IDs - Consistent file and folder naming - Appropriate data storage - Clear reagent labelling
Both paper and electronic lab notebooks are acceptable, provided records are complete, legible, and up to date.

title: Lab Expectations
text:
Communication norms

Day-to-day communication

Mattermost is the primary platform for day-to-day lab communication
Use Mattermost for quick questions, coordination, and updates
Email should be used for formal communication, external contacts, or administrative matters



Meetings

PhD students are expected to have regular supervisor meetings, typically weekly or biweekly, as agreed with their supervisor
Lab members should come prepared to meetings with:

Key updates
Questions or points requiring input
Relevant figures or data when appropriate


Meeting frequency and format may evolve over time and should be revisited as projects progress.

title: Lab Expectations
text:
Ownership and responsibility
Lab members are expected to take ownership of their work.
This includes responsibility for: - Experimental planning and execution - Proper documentation and data storage - Maintenance of personal reagents and samples - Cleaning up after experiments - Following up on results and action items
Asking for help is encouraged, particularly when blocked or uncertain.
Waiting too long to raise issues can slow progress and create avoidable problems.

title: Lab Expectations
text:
Shared resources and lab citizenship
The lab relies on shared resources, including equipment, reagents, and space.
Expectations include: - Leaving shared equipment clean and ready for the next user - Returning reagents and consumables to their correct location - Clearly labelling personal materials - Reporting broken equipment, low stock, or safety issues promptly
Good lab citizenship is essential for a functional and supportive environment.

title: Lab Expectations
text:
Safety and compliance
All lab members must: - Follow applicable safety regulations and institutional requirements - Complete required inductions (e.g. S2, iFET) before performing relevant work - Adhere to animal facility rules when applicable
If unsure about safety or compliance, lab members are expected to pause work and ask.
No experiment is urgent enough to justify unsafe practices.

title: Lab Expectations
text:
Expectations around supervision
Supervision is a shared responsibility.
Supervisors commit to: - Regular meetings and availability for discussion - Clear communication of priorities and expectations - Constructive feedback on data and progress - Support in training, troubleshooting, and career development - Guidance on publications, presentations, and PhD milestones
Lab members are encouraged to communicate openly about challenges, workload, and progress.

title: Lab Expectations
text:
Raising issues and resolving problems
If issues arise (scientific, organisational, or interpersonal): - Raise them early - Where possible, discuss directly with the relevant person - If needed, involve a supervisor or senior lab member
The goal is resolution, not blame.

title: Lab Expectations
text:
Scope and limitations
This document: - Describes how the lab operates - Sets shared expectations and norms
It does not: - Replace institutional policies - Override safety regulations - Define employment contracts

title: Lab Expectations
text:
Notes
These expectations are intended to evolve with the lab.
Suggestions for improvement or clarification are welcome and should be raised so this document remains accurate and useful.

title: Onboarding
text:
This section contains all information required for onboarding new PhD students joining the lab.
It is intended to: - Provide a clear onboarding pathway - Define expectations and standards - Centralise practical information needed to work effectively in the lab and institute
This section complements (but does not replace) lab protocols and experimental SOPs.

title: Onboarding
text:
This section contains all information required for onboarding new PhD students joining the lab.
It is intended to: - Provide a clear onboarding pathway - Define expectations and standards - Centralise practical information needed to work effectively in the lab and institute
This section complements (but does not replace) lab protocols and experimental SOPs.

title: Onboarding
text:
How to use this section

New PhD students

Start with the Onboarding checklist
Complete mandatory items in the first weeks
Use the remaining pages as reference material



Supervisors and lab members

Use this section as the canonical reference for onboarding
Avoid duplicating onboarding instructions elsewhere
Update pages here rather than sharing ad hoc documents

title: Onboarding
text:
Core onboarding document

Onboarding checklist
A time-ordered checklist covering access, training, expectations, and setup.

title: Onboarding
text:
Section overview

Access
Account setup, software access, computing resources, and booking systems.


Lab information
Day-to-day lab operation, expectations, etiquette, communication norms, and lab-specific models and techniques.


Institute
Overview of the institute, research groups, shared models, techniques, and core facilities.


Training
Mandatory training requirements and standards, including data handling and reproducibility.


Administration
University and institute administrative information relevant to PhD students.


Templates
Reusable forms and acknowledgement documents related to onboarding.

title: Onboarding
text:
Scope and boundaries
This onboarding section: - Describes what exists and what is expected - Links to protocols and SOPs where appropriate
It does not: - Contain experimental protocols - Replace safety or ethics training - Serve as a troubleshooting guide for experiments

title: Onboarding
text:
Questions or missing information
If information is missing or unclear: - First, check whether it exists elsewhere in the documentation - If not, raise it with your supervisor or a senior lab member so it can be added here
This onboarding documentation is intended to evolve with the lab.

title: Isolation of Human PBMCs from Whole Blood by Ficoll Gradient
text:
Protocol ID: HUM-BLD-PBMC-ISO-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino

title: Isolation of Human PBMCs from Whole Blood by Ficoll Gradient
section: Step 1 – Tube labelling and blood dilution
text:
Step 1 – Tube labelling and blood dilution

Label 50 mL conical tubes for each blood sample.
For each sample, add whole blood to a 50 mL tube:

Transfer up to 17.5 mL whole blood per 50 mL tube.

Dilute blood 1:2 with R0 medium (RPMI without FCS; BUF-GEN-R0-MED-001):

Add 17.5 mL R0 to 17.5 mL blood (total 35 mL).

If using less than 17.5 mL blood, top up to 35 mL with R0.








Note



Dilution with R0 reduces viscosity, improves layering on Ficoll, and can improve separation quality.

title: Isolation of Human PBMCs from Whole Blood by Ficoll Gradient
section: Step 2 – Ficoll layering and gradient centrifugation
text:
Step 2 – Ficoll layering and gradient centrifugation

In a fresh 50 mL tube, add 10 mL Ficoll (density gradient medium).
Using a 10 mL serological pipette, slowly overlay the 35 mL diluted blood onto the Ficoll:

Hold the Ficoll tube at a gentle angle.
Carefully dispense the diluted blood onto the Ficoll surface, avoiding mixing.
Maximum volume of diluted blood per tube: 35 mL.

Prepare all Ficoll gradients required and ensure they are balanced.
Centrifuge at 450 g (rcf) for 30 min at room temperature with:

Acceleration: 2

Deceleration: 1 (minimal brake)

During centrifugation, prepare 10 mL tubes containing 3 mL R0 (2 tubes per Ficoll gradient) for PBMC collection.

title: Isolation of Human PBMCs from Whole Blood by Ficoll Gradient
section: Step 3 – Harvest of PBMC layer and first wash
text:
Step 3 – Harvest of PBMC layer and first wash

After centrifugation, identify:

Plasma / diluted medium layer on top.
A white, “fluffy” PBMC layer at the plasma/Ficoll interface.
Ficoll layer.
Pellet of erythrocytes and granulocytes at the bottom.

Using a sterile transfer pipette, gently harvest the PBMC layer:

Carefully aspirate the interface and transfer to a 10 mL tube containing 3 mL R0.
Continue until the visible fluffy layer is removed.

For each gradient, distribute the collected PBMCs across two 10 mL tubes (each with 3 mL R0).
Centrifuge the 10 mL tubes at 400 g for 10 min at room temperature:

Acceleration: 9

Deceleration: 9

Carefully remove and discard the supernatant without disturbing the cell pellets.

title: Isolation of Human PBMCs from Whole Blood by Ficoll Gradient
section: Step 4 – Second wash and resuspension in R10
text:
Step 4 – Second wash and resuspension in R10

Resuspend each PBMC pellet in 3 mL R0.
Combine two pellets into one tube and top up to 10 mL R0.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 min at room temperature:

Acceleration: 9

Deceleration: 9

Remove and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 10 mL R10 (complete RPMI with 10 % FCS; BUF-GEN-R10-MED-001).
If multiple gradients were processed for the same sample, combine their PBMC pellets into a single tube in R10.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 min at room temperature.
Remove and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 1–10 mL R10, depending on pellet size and planned downstream use.

title: Isolation of Human PBMCs from Whole Blood by Ficoll Gradient
text:
Step 5 – Counting and cryopreservation (optional)

Mix the cell suspension gently and take a small aliquot for counting with trypan blue or an equivalent viability dye.
Calculate the total number of viable PBMCs.
For cryopreservation, aim for a final concentration of 10 × 10⁶ cells/mL per cryovial.


5.1 Preparation of 2× freezing medium (BUF-GEN-FREEZE-MIX-001)

Prepare 2× freezing medium by mixing:

7 mL R0

1 mL FCS

2 mL DMSO
(Final: R0 + 10 % FCS + 20 % DMSO; 2× relative to standard 10 % DMSO freezing medium.)

Keep the 2× freezing medium on ice and protected from light.



5.2 Adjust cell concentration and freeze

Adjust PBMCs in R10 to 20 × 10⁶ cells/mL:

If only one cryovial is needed, pellet cells at 200 g for 5 min, remove supernatant, and resuspend so that the cell pellet is in 500 µL R10 (20 × 10⁶ cells/mL).

Add an equal volume of 2× freezing medium (BUF-GEN-FREEZE-MIX-001) to the cells:

Final concentration: 10 × 10⁶ cells/mL in 10 % DMSO.

Gently mix to avoid bubbles.
Dispense 1 mL of cell suspension into pre-cooled cryovials, labelled with:

Patient name or anonymised ID.
Sample type (PBMC).
Date.

Place cryovials into a pre-cooled controlled-rate freezing container (e.g. Mr Frosty) and transfer to a −70 °C or −80 °C freezer.
After at least overnight freezing, move cryovials to liquid nitrogen for long-term storage.

title: K-562 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Protocol ID: HUM-K562-CULTURE-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino

title: K-562 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 1 – Reagents and medium preparation

Pre-warm complete culture medium:

RPMI 1640

10% FCS

1% Pen/Strep


Pre-warm PBS (if washing is needed).

Label flasks with:

Cell line name (K-562)

Passage number

Date

Operator initials

title: K-562 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 2 – Thawing K-562 cells

Pre-warm 10–15 mL of complete medium to 37 °C.
Thaw a cryovial of K-562 cells in a 37 °C water bath:

Gently swirl and remove when only a small ice crystal remains.

Transfer contents into a 15 mL tube containing 10 mL pre-warmed complete medium.
Centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min at room temperature.
Remove supernatant and gently resuspend the pellet in 10–15 mL fresh complete medium.
Transfer cells to a T25 or T75 flask and incubate at 37 °C, 5% CO₂.







Note



The centrifugation step removes DMSO, preventing toxicity during recovery.

title: K-562 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 3 – Routine culture and passaging

Recommended density

Maintain between 2 × 10⁵ and 1 × 10⁶ cells/mL.



Procedure

Gently resuspend the culture by pipetting up and down.
Count cells using trypan blue or an automated counter.
If density > 1 × 10⁶ cells/mL:

Split culture 1:2 to 1:5 depending on growth.

Add fresh, pre-warmed complete medium to adjust culture to:

2–3 × 10⁵ cells/mL

Return to incubator (37 °C, 5% CO₂).







Warning



Do not allow cultures to sit for more than 3–4 days without splitting. Nutrient depletion leads to apoptosis and growth arrest.

title: K-562 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 4 – Short-term storage / holding conditions

Cultures may be held at 2–4 × 10⁵ cells/mL for 24–48 h without splitting.
If cultures appear slow or viability drops:

Increase medium volume

Spin down and resuspend in entirely fresh medium

title: K-562 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 5 – Cryopreservation of K-562 cells

Preparation of freezing medium

90% FCS + 10% DMSO
(or use BUF-GEN-FREEZE-MIX-001 diluted 1:1 with cell suspension)



Freezing procedure

Collect cells in exponential growth phase.
Centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min.
Resuspend in freezing medium at 1–10 × 10⁶ cells/mL.
Aliquot 1 mL into labelled cryovials.
Place vials into a controlled-rate freezing container (e.g. Mr Frosty).
Freeze at −70/−80 °C overnight.
Transfer vials to liquid nitrogen for long-term storage.

text:

title: KHYG-1 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Protocol ID: HUM-KHYG1-CULTURE-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino

title: KHYG-1 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 1 – Medium and reagent preparation

Prepare KHYG-1 complete medium based on R10 (BUF-GEN-R10-MED-001):

RPMI 1640

10% heat-inactivated FCS

1% Pen/Strep


Prepare IL-2 stock according to manufacturer’s instructions.
Immediately before use, supplement complete medium with IL-2:

Final concentration: 100–200 IU/mL (use a lab-validated concentration consistently).

Pre-warm:

KHYG-1 complete medium + IL-2

PBS (if washing is needed)
to 37 °C.








Note



IL-2 should not be stored long-term in medium; add fresh to pre-warmed R10 immediately before feeding or splitting cultures.

title: KHYG-1 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 2 – Thawing KHYG-1 cells

Remove a cryovial of KHYG-1 cells from liquid nitrogen and immediately place it in a 37 °C water bath.
Gently swirl the vial until only a small ice crystal remains (1–2 min).
Disinfect the outside of the vial with 70% ethanol and transfer to a biosafety cabinet.
Transfer the vial contents to a 15 mL tube containing 9–10 mL pre-warmed KHYG-1 complete medium without IL-2 to dilute DMSO.
Centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min at room temperature.
Carefully aspirate the supernatant without disturbing the cell pellet.
Resuspend the cell pellet gently in 10–15 mL pre-warmed KHYG-1 complete medium with IL-2.
Transfer cells to an appropriate flask (e.g. T25 or T75).
Place the flask in a 37 °C, 5% CO₂ incubator.







Warning



Do not leave cells in freezing medium (DMSO-containing) after thawing. Wash promptly to minimise DMSO toxicity.

title: KHYG-1 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 3 – Routine culture and passaging

Recommended density range

Maintain cultures between approximately 2 × 10⁵ and 1 × 10⁶ cells/mL.



Monitoring and splitting

Gently resuspend the culture by pipetting up and down or gently swirling the flask.
Remove a small aliquot for counting and viability assessment.
If the cell density exceeds 1 × 10⁶ cells/mL, split the culture:

Remove a defined volume of culture (e.g. half to three-quarters of the flask volume).
Replace with an equal volume of fresh pre-warmed KHYG-1 medium with IL-2.
This corresponds to approximately a 1:2–1:4 split, depending on growth.

Aim to re-establish cultures at 2–3 × 10⁵ cells/mL after splitting.
Return flasks to the incubator (37 °C, 5% CO₂).



Medium change for lower-density cultures

If cells are at acceptable density but medium appears acidic or exhausted:

Gently resuspend cells.

Transfer to a 15 mL tube and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min.

Aspirate supernatant and resuspend in fresh medium with IL-2 at the desired density.

Return to flask and incubator.








Note



Maintain consistent IL-2 concentrations at each passage and medium change. Record IL-2 lot numbers for traceability.

title: KHYG-1 Cell Line Culture Protocol
section: Step 4 – Short-term maintenance and experimental setup
text:
Step 4 – Short-term maintenance and experimental setup

For experiments, seed KHYG-1 cells at a defined density consistent with experimental requirements (e.g. 2–3 × 10⁵ cells/mL).
Use fresh medium with IL-2 on the day before and the day of the experiment to ensure cells are in active growth phase.
Avoid using cultures older than a defined passage number (e.g. >20–25 passages post-thaw) for critical experiments; restart from frozen stock as needed.

title: KHYG-1 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 5 – Cryopreservation of KHYG-1 cells

Freezing medium

Standard freezing medium for KHYG-1:

90% FCS + 10% DMSO
or

Cell suspension in R10 mixed 1:1 with BUF-GEN-FREEZE-MIX-001 (2× freezing medium) to yield final 10% DMSO.




Freezing procedure

Ensure KHYG-1 cells are in exponential growth phase (healthy, non-overgrown cultures).
Transfer the culture to a 15 or 50 mL tube and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and gently resuspend the pellet in freezing medium at 5–10 × 10⁶ cells/mL.
Aliquot 1 mL of cell suspension per labelled cryovial (include cell line name, passage number, date, and your initials).
Place vials into a controlled-rate freezing container (e.g. Mr Frosty).
Freeze at −70/−80 °C for at least 12–24 hours.
Transfer vials to liquid nitrogen for long-term storage.







Warning



Avoid extended handling of cells at room temperature in freezing medium; DMSO is toxic and should be minimised outside of the controlled freezing process.

title: Lab Naming and Versioning Guide
text:
Purpose
This document defines the naming conventions and identifier system used across the Corvino Lab protocol library. These rules ensure:

Consistency across all .qmd protocol and buffer files

Stable, human-readable identifiers

Clear separation of identity (protocol_id) from versioning (version:)

Scalable indexing as the repository grows

This naming guide governs all protocol, buffer, and supporting document files.




Identifier Principles
Each file includes a stable identifier (protocol_id) that never changes once assigned.
Document versions, however, reflect revisions and updates over time.
Identifiers are:

Human-readable

Hierarchical

Independent of filenames

Independent of version numbers




Identifier Structure
All identifiers follow this structure:
<DOMAIN>-<TOPIC>-<TYPE>-<ID>
Where:

DOMAIN
Defines biological context or system
Examples: - MUS → mouse
- HUM → human
- CELL → cell-line–based procedure
- GEN → general or cross-species workflows


TOPIC
Defines the primary experimental or biological theme
Examples: - LCMV → LCMV virology workflows
- PTPRC → genotyping or CD45 locus assays
- FLOW → flow cytometry
- RNA → RNA extraction or analysis


TYPE
A concise descriptor of the method class
Examples: - PROD → virus production
- PLA → plaque assay
- FFA → focus-forming assay
- QPCR → quantitative PCR
- GENO → genotyping
- PROP → propagation medium or cell maintenance
- MED → assay or experimental medium


ID
A three-digit number (001, 002, …) indicating discrete methods inside the same category.
Important:
The ID increments only when a new, distinct protocol or buffer is added—not when updating or revising an existing file.




Versioning
Versions are tracked exclusively in the YAML header:
version: "v1.0"

Version increases reflect evolutionary changes to the same protocol or buffer.

protocol_id remains unchanged across all updates.

Examples: - v1.0 → initial release
- v1.1 → minor modifications
- v2.0 → major revision
Never encode the version inside the protocol_id.



When to Assign a New ID (001 → 002)
A new ID is assigned when:

The protocol constitutes a novel method, not just a revision

The workflow differs in a functionally meaningful way

A buffer has a distinct formulation or different intended use

An assay variant is introduced (e.g., fluorescent plaque assay, alternate overlay formulation, new primer system)

Examples:

Virus Production

MUS-LCMV-PROD-001 → standard T75 BHK or L929 production

MUS-LCMV-PROD-002 → roller-bottle high-volume culture system



Assays

MUS-LCMV-PLA-001 → crystal violet plaque assay

MUS-LCMV-PLA-002 → fluorescent immunoplaque assay



Genotyping

MUS-PTPRC-GENO-001 → Ptprc SNP genotyping

MUS-PTPRC-GENO-002 → multiplexed three-primer allelic discrimination assay



Buffers

BUF-BHK-PROP-001 → standard BHK propagation medium

BUF-BHK-PROP-002 → serum-free BHK propagation medium





Filenames
Filenames describe the file content and follow this structure:

Protocols
prot_<domain>_<topic>_<method>.qmd
Examples: - prot_mus_lcmv_multi_strain_production.qmd - prot_mus_lcmv_plaque_assay_vero.qmd - prot_mus_lcmv_focus_forming_assay.qmd - prot_mus_genotyping_ptprc_jaxboy_single_tube.qmd


Buffers
buf_<target>_<function>.qmd
Examples: - buf_bhk_propagation_medium.qmd - buf_vero_propagation_medium.qmd - buf_lcmv_plaque_assay_medium.qmd




Required YAML Fields
Each .qmd file must include:
title:
author:
date:
version:
protocol_id:
Example:
protocol_id: "MUS-LCMV-PROD-001"
version: "v1.0"



Protocol ID Examples (Current Library)

LCMV Methods

MUS-LCMV-PROD-001 → LCMV multi-strain production protocol

MUS-LCMV-PLA-001 → Vero cell plaque assay

MUS-LCMV-FFA-001 → Focus-forming assay

MUS-LCMV-QPCR-001 → GP-based qPCR viral load assay



Genotyping

MUS-PTPRC-GENO-001 → Ptprc (CD45.1/2) allele SNP genotyping



Buffers

BUF-BHK-PROP-001 → BHK propagation medium

BUF-VERO-PROP-001 → Vero propagation medium

BUF-LCMV-PLA-001 → LCMV plaque assay medium





Rules for Future Expansion

Maintain readability: avoid unnecessary abbreviations.

Keep identifiers short but descriptive.

Ensure no collisions within each TOPIC–TYPE group.

Do not remove or reuse IDs, even if protocols become deprecated.

Always update the version number when content changes.




Version History








Version
Date
Description




v1.0
2025-08-01
Original naming guide.


v1.1
2025-12-02
Expanded to include LCMV protocol classes, buffer categories, and new genotyping schema.

title: ARCHIVAL Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
text:
Protocol ID: ARCHIVAL-MUS-LIV-NLC-ISO-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino

title: ARCHIVAL Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
text:
Step 1 – Preparation and setup

Pre-cool solutions

Pre-cool PBS on ice for liver perfusion and transport.

Label collection vessels (choose one option per experiment)

Option A: 6-well plate collection

Label one well per mouse in a 6-well plate.
Add ~3–5 mL ice-cold PBS per well.

Option B: 50 mL tube collection

Label one 50 mL conical tube per liver.
Add 5 mL ice-cold PBS per tube.


Label dissociation and processing tubes

Label gentleMACS C-tubes (or equivalent) for each liver.
Label additional 50 mL tubes as required for downstream steps.

Prepare buffers (see separate buffer protocols)

Liver digestion buffer (BUF-MUS-LIV-DIG-001; collagenase IV + DNase I in PBS).
37% Percoll working solution (BUF-GEN-PERC-37PCT-001).
ACK lysis buffer (BUF-GEN-ACK-LYSIS-001).
FACS buffer (BUF-GEN-FACS-BUF-001), if required for downstream applications.

Warm digestion components

Turn on a water bath and set to 37 °C.
Place an aliquot of liver digestion buffer in the water bath to pre-warm.
If digestion buffer will be prepared later, pre-warm DMEM or PBS instead.

Equipment setup

Set a refrigerated benchtop centrifuge to 4 °C.
Ensure access to a gentleMACS instrument with an appropriate liver dissociation program.

Items to take to the animal facility

Ice bucket with ice-cold PBS.
6-well plates and/or pre-filled 50 mL tubes (as chosen above).
Sterile scissors and forceps.
10 mL syringes (one per mouse or per treatment group).
Needles for liver perfusion (recommended 25G or 26G).
Absorbent pads and waste container for perfusion runoff.

title: ARCHIVAL Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
section: Step 2 – Mouse sacrifice and liver perfusion
text:
Step 2 – Mouse sacrifice and liver perfusion

Sacrifice mice according to institutional and ethical guidelines (e.g. CO₂ asphyxiation followed by cervical dislocation, as approved).
Place the mouse in a supine position on a suitable surface.
Open the abdominal cavity to expose the liver and major vessels.
Perfuse the liver with ice-cold PBS via one of the following routes:

Inferior vena cava

Portal vein

Directly via the heart

Gently insert a needle into the chosen vessel and perfuse with PBS until the liver visibly blanches (typically ~5–10 mL per mouse).







Note



Efficient perfusion reduces blood content and improves the quality of density separation and downstream staining.



After perfusion, proceed immediately to liver collection.

title: ARCHIVAL Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
text:
Step 3 – Liver collection and mincing

Excise the perfused liver using sterile, autoclaved instruments.
Transfer the liver to the pre-labelled 50 mL conical tube or to the appropriate well of a 6-well plate containing ice-cold PBS.
Keep the tube or plate on ice at all times.
(Optional but highly recommended) Weigh the liver

Briefly place the liver on blotting paper to wick off excess liquid.
Weigh the liver and record the weight in the lab book.

Add 4 mL of pre-warmed liver digestion buffer to a labelled gentleMACS C-tube (one tube per liver).
Transfer the liver into the gentleMACS C-tube containing digestion buffer.
Using sterile curved scissors, mince the liver directly within the gentleMACS C-tube until tissue fragments are approximately ~2–3 mm.
Secure the C-tube onto the gentleMACS instrument.







Note



Ensure all tissue pieces are fully submerged in digestion buffer and not stuck to the walls or base of the tube.



Place the warming sleeve over the tube.
Run program HH17 (17-minute digestion).







Warning



After starting the run, confirm that all tubes are correctly seated and rotating properly.
If a tube is not spinning, stop the run, remove the tube, reseat it, and restart the program.








Important



Do not leave livers in digestion buffer for prolonged periods. Over-digestion can strip surface epitopes and negatively impact downstream staining and phenotyping.
Note: the gentleMACS instrument does not beep when the program finishes—set a timer or alarm before starting the run.








Warning



Make sure the gentleMACS C-tube is firmly closed and correctly positioned. Leaks during the run can lead to sample loss and contamination of the instrument.

title: ARCHIVAL Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
section: Step 5 – Removal of hepatocytes and washing
text:
Step 5 – Removal of hepatocytes and washing

After digestion, transfer the liver cell suspension from the C-tube into a 50 mL conical tube.
Rinse the C-tube with ice-cold PBS and add the rinse to the same 50 mL tube to maximize yield.
Bring the volume up to 50 mL with ice-cold PBS.
Centrifuge at 50 g for 2 min at 4 °C to sediment hepatocytes.
Carefully transfer the supernatant (containing lymphocytes and smaller cells) to a fresh 50 mL tube without disturbing the hepatocyte pellet.
Adjust the volume to 50 mL with ice-cold PBS.
Centrifuge at 550 g for 10 min at 4 °C.
Discard the supernatant and keep the cell pellet on ice.

title: ARCHIVAL Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
section: Step 6 – 37 % Percoll enrichment of liver-associated lymphocytes
text:
Step 6 – 37 % Percoll enrichment of liver-associated lymphocytes

While the liver samples are pelleting, aliquot 10 mL of 37% Percoll (BUF-GEN-PERC-37PCT-001, prepared in PBS) into labelled 15 mL conical tubes (one tube per liver).
Carefully aspirate the supernatant from the liver cell pellet in the 50 mL tube.
Using a transfer pipette, 1 mL pipette, or serological pipette, take up approximately 1 mL of 37% Percoll from the corresponding 15 mL tube and use it to gently resuspend the liver cell pellet in the 50 mL tube.
Transfer the resuspended cells back into the labelled 15 mL Percoll tube.
Repeat the rinse once or twice with additional small volumes of Percoll, if needed, to ensure all remaining liver cells are recovered from the 50 mL tube.
Cap the 15 mL tube and invert gently 2–3 times to ensure complete mixing.
Centrifuge at 800 × g for 20 min at room temperature (RT; ~20–22 °C) using:

Moderate acceleration (e.g. acc 7)
Minimal brake (e.g. br 1) to avoid disturbing the gradient








Important



Do not leave liver samples in Percoll for longer than necessary. Prolonged exposure can reduce cell viability and negatively impact downstream applications. Plan spins and downstream steps in advance.








Warning



Avoid high brake settings during Percoll centrifugation. Abrupt braking can disrupt the gradient and reduce lymphocyte enrichment.



After centrifugation, carefully asiprate the supernatant.
Resuspend the enriched lymphocyte pellet in 20–30 mL ice-cold PBS.
Centrifuge at 550 g) for 10 min at 4 °C.
Discard the supernatant and keep the pellet on ice.

title: ARCHIVAL Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
text:
STEP 7 – RBC lysis and filtration

Add 1 mL RBC lysis buffer per liver to the cell pellet:

HybriMax RBC Lysis Buffer: incubate for 5 minutes at room temperature, or

ACK lysis buffer: incubate for 2 minutes at room temperature.


Gently resuspend the pellet by pipetting or flicking immediately after adding buffer.

After incubation, quench the lysis by topping up to 50 mL with FACS Buffer.







Warning



Do not exceed the indicated incubation times. Over-lysis (particularly >5 minutes with HybriMax or >2 minutes with ACK) can reduce leukocyte viability.



Pass the suspension through a 70 µm cell strainer into a fresh 50 mL tube kept on ice.
Rinse the strainer with an additional 5–10 mL PBS if needed to recover remaining cells.
Centrifuge at 550 g for 10 min at 4 °C.
Discard the supernatant and keep the pellet on ice.

title: ARCHIVAL Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
text:
Step 8 – Final wash and resuspension

Resuspend the cell pellet in 10 mL ice-cold PBS.
Count cells and assess viability (e.g. trypan blue) as required.
Proceed with downstream applications (e.g. flow cytometry, sorting, or culture of NLCs).

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
Protocol ID: MUS-TMR-DIG-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 1 – Tumour excision and preparation

Euthanise the mouse using an approved method.
Expose the tumour and excise it with sterile scissors and forceps.
Remove fat, necrotic outer layers, and connective tissue using dissection scissors.
Rinse tumour briefly in cold PBS to remove blood and debris.
Transfer to a 10 cm petri dish containing cold PBS or FACS/MACS Buffer.







Tip



Remove necrotic regions; they clog strainers and reduce cell viability.

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 2 – Mincing

On a sterile petri dish, mince tumour tissue into very small pieces using scalpels or scissors.

Aim for 1–2 mm fragments for optimal enzyme penetration.

Transfer minced tissue into a 50 mL Falcon tube containing 5 mL Tumour Digestion Buffer (BUF-TMR-DIG-v1.0).

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 3 – Enzymatic digestion

Place tubes on a 37 °C benchtop shaker at 250 rpm.
Incubate for 30–45 minutes, depending on tumour density.
Every 10–15 minutes, remove the tube and gently shake or invert to encourage even digestion.







Warning



Over-digestion (>45 min) can reduce viability, especially in lymphocytes and myeloid cells.

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 4 – Mechanical dissociation

Add FACS/MACS Buffer to bring total volume to 20–25 mL.
Pour the digested tumour onto a 70 μm strainer placed over a 10 cm petri dish.
Using the back of a 5 mL syringe plunger, mash the tissue thoroughly through the strainer.

Rinse the strainer with additional cold FACS/MACS Buffer until no visible tissue remains.
Transfer the filtrate back into a clean 50 mL tube.
Top up to 50 mL with cold FACS/MACS Buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.
Carefully discard the supernatant.

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 5 – RBC lysis (if required)

If the suspension appears red or contains substantial blood, add 1 mL 1× RBC Lysis Buffer (HybriMax or equivalent).
Mix gently and incubate for 3–5 minutes at room temperature.
Immediately top up to 50 mL with cold FACS/MACS Buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.
Discard supernatant.

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 6 – Final wash and filtration

Loosen the pellet by gentle flicking.
Resuspend in 5–10 mL FACS/MACS Buffer.
Filter again through a fresh 70 μm strainer to remove remaining debris and aggregates.
Keep the final cell suspension on ice for downstream applications.

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 7 – Downstream applications
Proceed to:

Flow cytometry / TIL profiling

FACS sorting

Tumour microenvironment analyses

Cryopreservation of tumour-derived cell subsets

Single-cell RNA-seq / TCR-seq workflows

title: Mouse Lung Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
Protocol ID: MUS-LNG-DIG-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino

title: Mouse Lung Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 1 – Lung collection

Euthanise the mouse using an approved method.
Open the thoracic cavity to expose the lungs.
(Optional but recommended) Perfuse via the right ventricle with cold PBS until lungs visibly blanch, reducing RBC content.
Excise the entire lung block and place it in a 10 cm petri dish containing cold PBS or FACS/MACS Buffer.







Tip



Perfusion markedly improves final leukocyte purity and reduces RBC lysis requirements.

title: Mouse Lung Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 2 – Tissue mincing

Blot the lungs briefly on sterile tissue to remove excess fluid.
Transfer to a fresh 10 cm dish and mince thoroughly using scissors or scalpels until small fragments are obtained.
Transfer the minced lung into a 50 mL Falcon tube containing 5 mL Lung Digestion Buffer (see buffer protocol BUF-LNG-DIG-v1.0).

title: Mouse Lung Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 3 – Enzymatic digestion

Place tubes on a 37 °C benchtop shaker at 250 rpm.
Incubate for 30–35 minutes.







Warning



Over-digestion can decrease viability and negatively impact epithelial and myeloid populations.

title: Mouse Lung Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 4 – Mechanical dissociation

After digestion, add FACS/MACS Buffer to bring total volume to 25 mL.
Pour the suspension onto a 70 μm cell strainer placed on a 10 cm dish.
Mechanically mash the digested lung through the mesh using the back of a 5 mL syringe plunger.
Rinse the strainer with cold FACS/MACS Buffer until no visible tissue remains.
Transfer the filtered cell suspension back into a 50 mL tube.
Top up to 50 mL with cold FACS/MACS Buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.
Carefully discard the supernatant.

title: Mouse Lung Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 5 – RBC removal (if required)
Lung digests vary in RBC content. If erythrocytes are visible:

Add 1 mL 1× RBC Lysis Buffer (e.g. HybriMax) per lung.

Mix gently and incubate for 3–5 minutes at room temperature.
Immediately top up to 50 mL with cold FACS/MACS Buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.
Discard supernatant.







Note



If the lung was perfused effectively, this step may not be needed.

title: Mouse Lung Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 6 – Final wash and resuspension

Loosen pellet by gentle flicking or brief vortexing.
Resuspend in 5 mL FACS/MACS Buffer (or other desired volume).
Filter again through a fresh 70 μm strainer if clumping is observed.
Keep the suspension on ice until staining, sorting, or single-cell workflows.

title: Mouse Spleen Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
Protocol ID: MUS-SPL-DIS-001
Version: v1.1
Author: Dillon Corvino

title: Mouse Spleen Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 1 – Collection and preparation

Euthanise the mouse by an approved method.

Expose the spleen by opening the abdominal cavity.

Excise the spleen and remove connective tissue & adipose tissue
Place it into a petri dish or 15 mL Falcon tube containing cold PBS or FACS Buffer.

title: Mouse Spleen Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 2 – Mechanical dissociation

Place a 70 µm cell strainer over a 50 mL Falcon tube.

Transfer the spleen onto the strainer.

Using the back of a 5 mL syringe plunger, gently mash the spleen through the mesh until a homogenous suspension is obtained.

Rinse the strainer with FACS Buffer and top the tube up to 50 mL.







Note



Max of 2 spleens per tube/strainer

title: Mouse Spleen Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 3 – Wash and centrifugation

Centrifuge the 50 mL tube at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.

Carefully pour off the supernatant.

title: Mouse Spleen Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 4 – RBC lysis

Add RBC lysis buffer to the cell pellet (1 mL per spleen):

ACK lysis buffer: incubate for 1.5–2 minutes at room temperature, or

HybriMax RBC Lysis Buffer: incubate for 4–5 minutes at room temperature.


Gently resuspend immediately by pipetting or flicking to ensure uniform lysis.

Quench the reaction by topping up to 50 mL with FACS Buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.







Warning



Do not exceed the indicated incubation times. Over-incubation is the most common cause of reduced leukocyte viability. If red cells remain, repeat a short second lysis rather than extending the incubation.








Note



ACK lysis buffer is stronger and faster but less forgiving. HybriMax is milder and preferred when viability is critical (e.g. downstream scRNA-seq or adoptive transfer).

title: Mouse Spleen Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 5 – Filtration and final wash

Filter the suspension through a fresh 70 µm strainer into a clean tube.

Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.

Carefully discard supernatant.

Resuspend the pellet in 5 mL FACS Buffer (or a volume appropriate for your downstream assay).

title: Mouse Spleen Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 6 – Downstream handling
Proceed immediately to:

Flow cytometry staining

FACS sorting

Cryopreservation

Functional assays

Keep cells on ice until use.

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
Protocol ID: MUS-LIV-DIG-001
Version: v1.1
Author: Dillon Corvino

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 1 – Preparation and setup

Pre-cool collection solutions

Pre-cool PBS or FACS buffer on ice for liver perfusion and tissue collection.

Label collection vessels (choose one option per experiment)

Option A: 6-well plate collection

Label one well per mouse in a 6-well plate.
Add 3–5 mL ice-cold PBS or FACS buffer per well.

Option B: 50 mL tube collection

Label one 50 mL conical tube per liver.
Add 5 mL ice-cold PBS or FACS buffer per tube.


Label dissociation and processing tubes

Label gentleMACS C-tubes (or equivalent) for each liver.
Label additional 50 mL tubes as required for downstream processing steps.

Prepare buffers

Liver digestion buffer.
37% Percoll working solution.
ACK lysis buffer, if required.
FACS buffer for washes and final resuspension.

Warm digestion components

Pre-warm a water bath to 37 °C.
Place an aliquot of liver digestion buffer in the water bath to equilibrate.
If digestion buffer will be prepared immediately before use, pre-warm DMEM instead.

Equipment setup

Pre-cool a benchtop centrifuge to 4 °C.
Ensure access to a gentleMACS instrument with an appropriate liver dissociation program.

Items to take to the animal facility

Ice bucket with ice-cold PBS or FACS buffer.
6-well plates and/or pre-filled 50 mL tubes (as selected above).
Sterile scissors and forceps.
10 mL syringes (one per mouse or per treatment group).
Needles for liver perfusion (25G or 26G recommended).
Absorbent pads and a waste container for perfusion runoff.

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 2 – Liver harvest and perfusion

Euthanise the mouse according to institutional and ethical guidelines (e.g. CO₂ asphyxiation or other approved method).
Place the mouse in a supine position and perform a midline incision to open the abdominal cavity.
Expose the liver and major vessels (Inferior vena cava and portal vein).
Load a 5 mL syringe with ice-cold FACS buffer and attach a 25–27 G needle.
Perfuse the liver via one of the following routes:

Inferior vena cava (preferred)

Portal vein
Directly via the heart

Slowly perfuse with ~5–10 mL FACS buffer per mouse until the liver visibly blanches.







Note



Efficient perfusion reduces blood content and improves hepatocyte removal, density separation, and downstream staining quality.








Warning



Handle needles and sharps carefully and dispose of them immediately into an approved sharps container after perfusion.



Excise the liver carefully, removing the gallbladder.
Place the liver briefly on filter paper to blot excess buffer.

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
section: STEP 3 – Liver collection, weighing, and mincing
text:
STEP 3 – Liver collection, weighing, and mincing

Transfer the perfused liver to a pre-labelled collection vessel (on ice).
(Recommended) Weigh the liver:

Briefly blot on filter paper to remove excess liquid.
Record the liver weight.

Add 5 mL pre-warmed liver digestion buffer (in DMEM) to a labelled gentleMACS C-tube.
Transfer the liver into the gentleMACS C-tube.
Using sterile scissors, mince the liver directly in the C-tube until fragments are approximately 2–3 mm in size.
Ensure all tissue pieces are fully submerged in digestion buffer and not stuck to the tube walls.
Secure the C-tube onto the gentleMACS instrument and place the warming sleeve over the tube.
Run the appropriate liver digestion program (e.g. HH17, ~17 min).







Warning



Confirm that each C-tube is correctly seated and rotating before leaving the instrument.
If a tube is not spinning, stop the run, reseat the tube, and restart the program.








Important



Do not leave livers in digestion buffer beyond the programmed digestion time.
Over-digestion can strip surface epitopes and negatively impact downstream phenotyping.
Note: the gentleMACS instrument does not beep when the program finishes—set a timer before starting.

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 4 – Hepatocyte removal and washing

After digestion, transfer the entire liver cell suspension from the gentleMACS C-tube into a 50 mL conical tube.
Rinse the C-tube with ice-cold FACS buffer and add the rinse to the same tube to maximize yield.
Bring the volume up to 50 mL with ice-cold FACS buffer.
Centrifuge at 50 g for 2 minutes at 4 °C to sediment hepatocytes.
Carefully transfer the supernatant (containing leukocytes) to a fresh 50 mL tube, avoiding disturbance of the hepatocyte pellet.
Adjust the volume to 50 mL with ice-cold FACS buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.
Discard the supernatant and keep the leukocyte pellet on ice for downstream processing.







Warning



Cell pellets from digested liver are often loose and poorly compacted.
When discarding supernatant by pouring, do so scarefully. Avoid flicking, shaking, or abrupt movements.

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 5 – 37% Percoll enrichment

Aliquot 10 mL of 37% Percoll into pre-labelled 15 mL conical tubes (one tube per liver).
Using a transfer pipette, resuspend the cell pellet using the small remaining dead volume.
Take up approximately 1 mL of 37% Percoll from the corresponding 15 mL tube and use it to rinse the 50 mL tube, resuspending any remaining cells.
Transfer the resuspended cells into the corresponding 15 mL tube containing 10 mL 37% Percoll.
Repeat the rinse 1–2 times with additional small volumes of Percoll (as needed) to recover all remaining cells from the 50 mL tube.
Cap the 15 mL tubes and invert gently 2–3 times to ensure an even cell suspension.
Centrifuge at 800 g for 20 minutes at room temperature (20–22 °C) using:

Acceleration: moderate (e.g. acc 7)
Brake: minimal (e.g. br 1)








Warning



Avoid high brake settings during Percoll centrifugation. Abrupt braking can disrupt the gradient and reduce lymphocyte enrichment.








Important



Do not leave liver samples in Percoll longer than necessary. Prolonged exposure can reduce viability and negatively impact downstream applications. Plan spins and next steps in advance.








Note



After the Percoll spin, a debris/hepatocyte-rich layer typically remains in the supernatant, while an enriched leukocyte pellet forms at the bottom of the tube.



Carefully aspirate or pour off the supernatant in one smooth motion without disturbing the pellet.
Keep tubes inverted briefly and gently dab the rim on paper towel to wick residual Percoll (avoid touching or dislodging the pellet).
Resuspend the pellet in 10–15 mL ice-cold FACS buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.
Discard the supernatant and keep the enriched leukocyte pellet on ice for downstream steps.

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 5 – RBC lysis

Add RBC lysis buffer to the cell pellet (0.5–1 mL per liver):

ACK lysis buffer: incubate for 30–60 seconds at room temperature, or

HybriMax RBC Lysis Buffer: incubate for 2–3 minutes at room temperature.


Gently resuspend immediately to distribute the buffer evenly.

Quench the reaction by topping up to 15 mL with FACS Buffer.
Pass the suspension through a 70 µm cell strainer into a fresh 50 mL tube kept on ice.
Rinse the strainer with an additional 5–10 mL FACS Buffer if needed to recover remaining cells.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.
Discard the supernatant and keep the pellet on ice.







Warning



Liver leukocytes are particularly sensitive to over-lysis. Do not exceed the stated incubation times, especially after enzymatic digestion or Percoll separation.








Note



RBC lysis is often unnecessary for liver samples when a Percoll gradient is used. If lysis is required, HybriMax is generally preferred due to its gentler action compared to ACK.

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 6 – Final resuspension

Resuspend the cell pellet in 1-5 mL ice-cold FACS Buffer
Count cells and assess viability (e.g. trypan blue) as required.
Proceed with downstream applications (e.g. flow cytometry, sorting, or culture of NLCs).







Tip



For single-cell sequencing applications, minimise the time from tissue harvest to final resuspension, keep samples on ice whenever possible after digestion, and consider additional debris/dead cell removal steps if yields permit.

title: LCMV Infection Models (WE, Clone 13, Docile, Armstrong)
text:
Protocol ID: MUS-INF-LCMV-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino

title: LCMV Infection Models (WE, Clone 13, Docile, Armstrong)
text:
Virus stock handling and preparation
LCMV-WE, LCMV-Clone 13, LCMV-Docile, and LCMV-Armstrong virus stocks are propagated and titrated as previously described in the literature and internal Abdullah Lab SOPs.

Virus stocks are stored at −80 °C in single-use aliquots.
Repeated freeze–thaw cycles must be avoided.


Thawing

Virus aliquots are rapidly thawed immediately before use.
Thawing is performed in a 37 °C water bath until the aliquot is just thawed.
Aliquots are removed promptly from the water bath and placed immediately on ice.
Virus is kept on ice during dilution and injection.
Repeated freeze–thaw cycles must be avoided.



Dilution buffer

Virus stocks are diluted in sterile, endotoxin-free PBS.
No serum or supplements are added unless explicitly required by internal SOP.
Dilutions are prepared fresh on the day of infection.

title: LCMV Infection Models (WE, Clone 13, Docile, Armstrong)
text:
Infection doses and routes
Mice are infected intravenously (i.v.) via the lateral tail vein using the following Abdullah Lab standard doses:

LCMV-Clone 13: 2 × 10⁶ plaque-forming units (PFU)
LCMV-WE: 2 × 10⁴ plaque-forming units (PFU)

Other strains (Docile, Armstrong) are included for reference and comparative studies as outlined below.

Injection parameters

Injection volume: 200 µL per mouse
Syringe: insulin syringe
Needle gauge: 27G–30G
Injections are performed slowly to ensure proper intravenous delivery.
Successful i.v. injection is confirmed by lack of resistance and absence of subcutaneous bleb formation.

title: LCMV Infection Models (WE, Clone 13, Docile, Armstrong)
text:
Post-infection monitoring

Body weight and general health are monitored daily during the first week post infection.
Monitoring frequency is adjusted according to infection severity and institutional guidelines.
Humane endpoints are applied as defined in approved protocols.

title: LCMV Infection Models (WE, Clone 13, Docile, Armstrong)
text:
LCMV-WE (2 × 10⁴ PFU i.v.)

NLCs accumulate prominently in the liver.
Peak frequency occurs at approximately day 7 post infection.
Elevated NLC levels are maintained through at least day 30 post infection.
This model supports both early and long-term NLC analyses.

title: LCMV Infection Models (WE, Clone 13, Docile, Armstrong)
text:
LCMV-Clone 13 (2 × 10⁶ PFU i.v.)

NLCs peak early, around day 5 post infection.
A sharp contraction occurs by ~day 7, followed by gradual decline through day 30.
The effective experimental window for NLC analysis is day 4–7 post infection.
Sampling outside this window will substantially underestimate NLC abundance.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
text:
Protocol ID: MUS-SPL-NK-PROLIF-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
section: Step 1 – Preparations on the day before sort
text:
Step 1 – Preparations on the day before sort

Determine:

Mouse genotypes (e.g. WT, CD160 KO, IFNAR1 KO, etc.).
Number of mice per genotype and per experimental group.
Number of timepoints and replicates for the proliferation assay.

Assign mice to the experiment in PyRAT (or equivalent animal management system) and record a cohort ID.
Export the list of mice and provide it to the animal facility (e.g. Kathrin) as required.
Prepare sort collection tubes:

For each sorted population (e.g. total NK, CD160⁺ NK, CD160⁻ NK), prepare 15 mL Falcon tubes.
Add 2–3 mL FCS to each tube.
Place tubes on a roller at 4 °C (cold room) or in the fridge overnight to allow coating.

Prepare 50 mL Falcon tubes with 1× PBS for spleen harvest:

One tube per mouse or per pooled group (as per experimental design).
Store at 4 °C until use.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
section: Step 2 – Preparations on the day of sort: spleen harvest
text:
Step 2 – Preparations on the day of sort: spleen harvest

Bring prepared PBS tubes and transport containers to the animal facility.
Remove cages of mice assigned to the experiment:

Pool mice in groups as required (e.g. groups of 10 within a cage).
Sacrifice mice (e.g. in CO₂ chamber) according to institutional guidelines.

Harvest spleens:

Place each spleen into a 50 mL tube containing cold PBS (5–10 mL).
Keep tubes on ice during transport back to the lab.

Refer to the relevant SOP for detailed organ harvest and splenocyte isolation, if needed.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
text:
Step 3 – Preparation of splenocyte suspensions

In a biosafety cabinet, transfer each spleen to a sterile Petri dish containing cold PBS.
Gently homogenise the spleen through a suitable cell strainer (e.g. 70 µm) using the plunger of a 5 or 10 mL syringe into a 50 mL tube.
Rinse the strainer with additional PBS to maximise cell recovery.
Centrifuge at ~400–500 g for 5 min at 4 °C.
Discard supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet in FACS buffer (BUF-GEN-FACS-BUF-001) or PBS, as appropriate for counting.
Count splenocytes and record total cell numbers.







Note



A rough guideline used in the original SOP is ~1 × 10⁸ splenocytes per mouse. This can be used for initial planning but always verify by counting.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
section: Step 4 – NK cell isolation from spleen
text:
Step 4 – NK cell isolation from spleen
Follow the instructions of the magnetic NK cell isolation kit (e.g. EasySep Mouse NK cell isolation kit) and the recommendations for temperature and volumes.

Calculate the total splenocyte count and volume needed for isolation:

For example, if using 14 spleens and assuming ~1 × 10⁸ cells per spleen, plan for ~1.4 × 10⁹ splenocytes.
Adjust volumes and kit reagent amounts accordingly.

Adjust the splenocyte suspension to 1 × 10⁸ cells/mL in FACS buffer or kit-specified buffer at room temperature.
For comparison of NK cells from two genotypes (e.g. WT vs CD160 KO):

Perform complete NK isolation as per the kit instructions for each genotype (full recommended reagent volumes per mL of cells).

For experiments requiring NK subsets (e.g. CD160⁺ vs CD160⁻ NK from WT mice):

Perform a pre-enrichment step:

Use the same kit but with half the indicated volume of isolation cocktail and magnetic beads per mL of cells (to enrich but not fully deplete other cells).


Keep reagents, buffers, and cells at room temperature during the magnetic isolation, as recommended by the kit.







Warning



Deviating from the manufacturer’s temperature recommendations (e.g. performing kit steps on ice instead of room temperature) can substantially reduce NK cell yield and purity.



After isolation or pre-enrichment, resuspend NK-enriched cells in PBS for CellTrace staining (see Step 5).

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
section: Step 5 – CellTrace staining of NK cells
text:
Step 5 – CellTrace staining of NK cells
This step uses CellTrace Violet (CTV) or CellTrace Blue (CTB) to track divisions.

Count enriched NK cells and calculate the volume needed for staining.
Resuspend NK cells at 1 × 10⁶ cells/mL in PBS (no FCS).
Prepare CTV or CTB according to the manufacturer’s instructions:

Reconstitute the vial in DMSO to create a concentrated stock.

Stain NK cells:

For CTV: use a final concentration corresponding to 1:5000 of the stock (as used in the original SOP).

For CTB: use a final concentration corresponding to 1:1000 of the stock.

Incubate at 37 °C for 15 min, protected from light.
Controls:

Before staining, remove aliquots of cells for:

Unstained control.
Live/dead-only control.

After CTV/CTB staining, remove an aliquot for:

CTV/CTB single-stain control.


Quench and wash:

Add complete NK medium (BUF-MUS-NK-MED-001; cRPMI with supplements and IL-15 omitted at this stage or added as per your lab practice) to a volume sufficient to quench the dye.
Centrifuge at ~400 g for 5 min.
Discard supernatant and resuspend in fresh NK medium or FACS buffer as required for subsequent surface staining.








Warning



Incorrect CTV/CTB concentration or prolonged staining can cause toxicity and alter NK cell behaviour. Always work within titrated ranges and avoid exceeding 15 min at 37 °C.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
section: Step 6 – Surface staining for sorting (if sorting NK subsets)
text:
Step 6 – Surface staining for sorting (if sorting NK subsets)
If sorting CD160⁺ and CD160⁻ NK subsets or other NK subsets, perform surface staining after CTV/CTB labelling.

Prepare surface staining master mixes in FACS buffer (BUF-GEN-FACS-BUF-001), including:

Fc block (e.g. 1:200).

Surface antibodies for NK identification and subset discrimination (e.g. NK1.1, NKp46, CD3, CD160, etc.).

Live/dead dye, if not already integrated earlier.

Stain up to 5 × 10⁶ cells in 50 µL surface staining mix per tube.
Incubate for 30 min at 4 °C, protected from light.
Add ~4× the staining volume of FACS buffer to wash.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 min, discard supernatant.
Resuspend the cell pellet at 10–15 × 10⁶ cells/mL in PBS for sorting (e.g. for a 70 µm nozzle).
Prepare single-colour controls:

Single-stain controls for each fluorochrome in PBS.
Live/dead controls in beads and/or cells.

Keep all stained cells and controls cold (4 °C or on ice) and protected from light until sorting.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
text:
Step 7 – Sorting and collection

Set up the cell sorter (e.g. BD FACS Aria) with the appropriate nozzle (e.g. 70 µm) and sorting strategy for NK cells and subsets.
Use FCS-coated collection tubes prepared in Step 1:

Add an appropriate volume of NK medium (BUF-MUS-NK-MED-001) to each tube before sorting.

Sort NK populations:

For total NK proliferation: sort or gate total NK cells as required.

For subset proliferation (e.g. CD160⁺ vs CD160⁻): sort each subset into separate collection tubes.

Keep collection tubes at 4 °C or room temperature as appropriate and move them to the incubator as soon as sorting is complete.







Tip



Monitor sort purity and yield during the run to ensure that enough events are collected for the planned timepoints and replicates.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
section: Step 8 – In vitro culture and proliferation assay
text:
Step 8 – In vitro culture and proliferation assay

After sorting, count the NK cell populations (e.g. using a microscope or automated cell counter).
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 min and resuspend in NK medium (BUF-MUS-NK-MED-001) supplemented with IL-15.

Add IL-15 to a final concentration of 100 IU/mL immediately before plating.

Plate sorted NK cells in suitable culture plates (e.g. 96-well U- or flat-bottom plates):

Typical seeding density: 20–50 × 10³ cells per well in 200 µL NK medium + IL-15.

Adjust based on yield and number of timepoints.

Culture conditions:

Incubate plates at 37 °C, 5 % CO₂.
Include:

“Day 0” samples (can be fixed immediately after sorting).

Multiple timepoints (e.g. day 2, 3, 4, etc.).


Controls:

Unstimulated NK cells (IL-15 only).

NK cells with additional stimuli, if desired (cytokines, co-stimulation, etc.).

CTV/CTB single-stain and unstained controls (can be fixed early).

For each selected timepoint:

Harvest NK cells from the wells.
Optionally stain for additional surface markers (using standard FACS buffer and staining conditions).
Fix cells in 4 % PFA or Histofix as per your lab standard.








Note



The original SOP notes that Day 0 populations and single-stain controls can be fixed immediately for reference; subsequent timepoints should be acquired using the same cytometer settings as Day 0.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
text:
Step 9 – Acquisition and analysis

Acquire all timepoints on the same flow cytometer (e.g. Cytek Aurora) using:

The same voltage/PMT settings.
Consistent compensation and gating strategy.

When possible, use:

Counting beads and/or

A fixed acquisition volume and flow rate.

Analyse CellTrace dilution profiles for each NK population:

Determine the number of divisions.

Calculate proliferation indices and division indices as required.

Compare genotypes or conditions (e.g. WT vs KO, CD160⁺ vs CD160⁻).

text:

text:

title: LCMV Production: Unified Multi-Strain Protocol (Armstrong, Clone 13, WE, Docile)
text:
Armstrong

Classical acute strain.
Often propagated on BHK-21 cells at MOI 0.01–0.1 for 48 h.
Frequently used to generate high-titer stocks for i.p. or i.v. infections in the 2 × 10⁵–2 × 10⁶ PFU range.

title: LCMV Production: Unified Multi-Strain Protocol (Armstrong, Clone 13, WE, Docile)
text:
Clone 13

Armstrong-derived chronic strain with enhanced visceral tropism.
Grows well on BHK-21 cells; titers similar to or slightly lower than Armstrong for the same MOI/time.
For chronic infection models, typical i.v. doses are 2 × 10⁶ to 2 × 10⁷ PFU, depending on experimental design.

title: LCMV Production: Unified Multi-Strain Protocol (Armstrong, Clone 13, WE, Docile)
text:
WE

WE strain is viscerotropic and often used as an acute systemic infection model.
Commonly propagated on L929 cells, though BHK-21 also supports growth.
For hemorrhagic-like disease models, stock quality and titer consistency are critical.

title: LCMV Production: Unified Multi-Strain Protocol (Armstrong, Clone 13, WE, Docile)
text:
Docile

WE-derived persistent variant.
Grows on BHK-21 and L929 cells; replication in vitro may be slightly slower than WE in some systems.
Used for chronic infection models alternative to Clone 13.

title: LCMV Plaque Assay on Vero Cells
text:
Vero Cell Seeding

One day before infection, seed Vero cells in 6-well plates to achieve a 90–100% confluent monolayer on the day of infection.
Use Vero propagation medium and incubate at 37°C, 5% CO₂.







Tip



Aim for evenly distributed, healthy monolayers. Avoid overconfluency and large areas of cell-free plastic.

title: LCMV Plaque Assay on Vero Cells
text:
Overlay Medium
You can use either:

Methylcellulose-based overlay, or

Low-melting agarose overlay

A common approach is to mix equal volumes of:

2× plaque assay medium (see buffer file) and

2% methylcellulose or 2% agarose (cooled to ~42–45°C for agarose)

to obtain a final 1× medium with 1% methylcellulose or 1% agarose.
Prepare and keep overlay medium warm (37–42°C) until use.

title: Standard Flow Cytometry Staining (Surface, Intracellular, Intranuclear)
text:
Protocol ID: GEN-FLOW-STD-001
Version: v1.3
Author: Dillon Corvino

title: Standard Flow Cytometry Staining (Surface, Intracellular, Intranuclear)
text:
Step 1 – Plate setup and buffers

Prepare buffers:

FACS buffer (PBS + 2% FCS) — use only if tetramers are included
MACS buffer (PBS + 2% FCS + 2 mM EDTA) — default buffer

Prepare single-cell suspensions.
Count cells and adjust concentration to plate 2 × 10⁵ – 1 × 10⁶ cells per well.
Aliquot cells into a 96-well U- or V-bottom plate.
Keep plates on ice or at 4 °C.

title: Standard Flow Cytometry Staining (Surface, Intracellular, Intranuclear)
text:
Step 2 – Surface staining (with live/dead ± tetramers)
Surface staining is performed in a single master mix.

If tetramers are included → use FACS buffer (no EDTA)

If no tetramers are included → use MACS buffer

Antibody titration guidance (applies to all surface staining): - Surface antibodies: default 1:200 if titration data are unavailable. - Transcription factors or weakly expressed markers: default 1:50.

2.1 Prepare surface staining master mix
Prepare a 1× surface staining master mix in the appropriate buffer containing:

Fc block: 1:100
Live/dead dye (1× final concentration)
Surface antibodies (1× final concentration)
Optional: Tetramer(s), per manufacturer recommendation

Final volume: 50 µL per well






Note



When tetramers are included, staining is performed in FACS buffer without EDTA to avoid potential interference with multimer–TCR interactions.
Whether EDTA exclusion is strictly necessary remains under investigation and will be empirically evaluated within the lab.








Tip



After flicking off the supernatant, residual liquid in the dead volume can be used to resuspend cell pellets by briefly vortexing the plate at low speed to agitate the wells. This helps achieve uniform resuspension before adding the next reagent.




2.2 Staining

Resuspend each cell pellet in 50 µL surface staining master mix.
Incubate for 30 min on ice, protected from light.



2.3 Wash steps

Top up each well to 200 µL with MACS buffer.
Centrifuge at 1000 g for 2 min at 4 °C.
Flick off the supernatant.
Wash once more with 200 µL MACS buffer, centrifuge at 1000 g for 2 min at 4 °C, and flick.







Note



All antibodies and tetramers should be titrated for optimal performance. Default dilutions are provided as a starting point only.




2.4 Surface staining only

Resuspend pellets in 100–200 µL 4% PFA in PBS.
Wrap the plate in aluminium foil to protect from light and clearly label with name and date.
Store at 4 °C, protected from light, until acquisition.

title: Standard Flow Cytometry Staining (Surface, Intracellular, Intranuclear)
text:
Step 3 – Fixation and permeabilization
This step assumes use of: - BD Cytofix/Cytoperm (cytoplasmic targets), or
- eBioscience FOXP3 fix/perm (intranuclear targets).

3.1 Initial fixation/permeabilization

Add 100 µL fix/perm solution per well.
Incubate 20 min on ice, protected from light.
Top up to 200 µL with 1× PermWash.
Centrifuge at 1000 g for 2 min at 4 °C and flick.
Resuspend in 200 µL PermWash.
Centrifuge at 1000 g for 2 min at 4 °C and flick.



3.2 Optional pause point

Resuspend pellets in 200 µL MACS buffer.
Wrap the plate in aluminium foil to protect from light and clearly label with name and date.
Store at 4 °C overnight, protected from light.







Note



If the protocol is paused at this step, the recovery steps below must be performed before proceeding to intracellular or intranuclear staining.




3.3 Restarting the protocol after pause point

Centrifuge the plate at 1000 g for 2 min at 4 °C.
Flick off the supernatant.
Resuspend pellets in 200 µL PermWash.
Incubate for 30 min on ice, protected from light.
Centrifuge at 1000 g for 2 min at 4 °C and flick.
Proceed directly to Step 4 – Intracellular or intranuclear staining.

title: Standard Flow Cytometry Staining (Surface, Intracellular, Intranuclear)
text:
Step 4 – Intracellular or intranuclear staining

Prepare an intracellular or intranuclear antibody master mix in the appropriate PermWash buffer (kit-specific):

Final volume: 50 µL per well

Resuspend each cell pellet in 50 µL of the antibody master mix.
Incubate 30 min on ice, protected from light, or incubate overnight at 4 °C.







Tip



For intranuclear targets (e.g. FOXP3, Helios, T-bet, Eomes), overnight antibody incubation at 4 °C can improve signal intensity, particularly for low-abundance or epitope-masked transcription factors.
Ensure plates are well sealed, clearly labelled, and protected from light during overnight incubation.








Warning



Overnight antibody incubation is not recommended for cytoplasmic intracellular targets (e.g. cytokines, granzymes, perforin). Prolonged incubation can increase background staining and does not typically improve signal for these antigens. Use 30–60 min incubations for intracellular (non-nuclear) targets.



Top up each well to 200 µL with PermWash.
Centrifuge at 1000 g for 2 min at 4 °C and flick off the supernatant.
Wash once more with 200 µL PermWash, centrifuge at 1000 g for 2 min at 4 °C, and flick.
Resuspend each pellet in 100–200 µL 4% PFA in PBS.
Wrap the plate in aluminium foil to protect from light and clearly label with name and date.
Store at 4 °C, protected from light, until acquisition.

title: Sony ID7000 Data Handling and Storage
text:
Using ID7000 Data Agent

FCS file export is handled by the ID7000 Data Agent
The Data Agent starts automatically when FCS export is initiated
The Data Agent icon appears in the task tray


Monitoring export status

Hover over the ID7000 Data Agent icon to view export progress and status
A log file documenting the export is written to the output folder



Opening the export folder

Right-click the ID7000 Data Agent icon
Select Open Latest Output Folder
Review exported files and the associated log file

title: Sony ID7000 Data Handling and Storage
text:
Mandatory folder structure






TipOne USER folder per user



Create one folder named with your username as a subfolder of USER on the desktop and use only this folder for all exports.


Recommended structure:
USER/
└── <username>/
    ├── fcs/
    ├── experiments/
    ├── reference_controls/
    ├── projects/
    │   ├── project_A/
    │   └── project_B/

You may save the export path in ID7000 Preferences
Use subfolders to separate:

FCS files
Experiment files
Reference controls
Project-specific datasets

title: Sony ID7000 Data Handling and Storage
section: Recommended workflow to reduce device usage time
text:
Recommended workflow to reduce device usage time






NoteEfficiency recommendation



To minimize time at the instrument PCs:



Perform experiment setup on:

External Analysis Workstation I (older, slower)

Export the experiment file (.exdat)
Import the experiment on the instrument PC
Perform unmixing adjustments on:
